metadata.case_name: Dattatraya Gurunath v. Kalasappa and others

facts.text: Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving surviving two widows Radhabai (senior) and Gangabai (junior) and a son Dattatraya.
Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.
Gangabai adopted the plaintiff Dattatraya Gurunath in 1943.

Plaintiff instituted suit on 15th March 1944 in forma pauperis claiming to be adopted son of Krishtarao by Gangabai, entitled to possession of adoptive father's properties and declaration regarding compensation money for land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

Defendants (sons and grandsons of first cousin of Krishtarao) disputed plaintiff's adoption on ground that Gangabai's power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving widow Sundarabai and son Jagannath to continue family line.
Gangabai in written statement supported plaintiff's claim and asserted senior widow Radhabai gave consent to adoption.
Trial judge upheld defendants' contention, dismissed suit; upheld factum of adoption but held Radhabai did not give consent; power to adopt extinguished when son died leaving son and widow.
High Court affirmed trial court decision; held Gangabai's power to adopt ended when her son died leaving son and widow to continue family line. No finding on Radhabai's consent.
Appeal before Supreme Court by special leave in forma pauperis.

legal_issues.text: Whether a widow can exercise power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of devolution of property or changes in family or other circumstances and even after a grandson has come on the scene but has subsequently died without leaving a widow or a son.

petitioner_arguments.text: Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to exercise of widow's power of adoption once acquired or possessed; power can be exercised during her lifetime when necessity arises for continuing line of her husband.

Power suspended during son's lifetime revives on son dying sonless and unmarried; logically revives when son, widow, grandson and his widow all die out; substitution for spiritual reasons essence, devolution of property accessory.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan (1933 L.R. 60 I.A. 242)

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule in Amarendra's case has no application; on death of grandson widow's power revives; cites Bapuji v. Gangaram (1941 I.L.R. Nagpur 178) and Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh (1945 I.L.R. 21 Luck. 1).

respondent_arguments.text: Though Hindu Shastric Law sets no limit, judicially recognised power not unlimited/absolute; comes to end when another heir comes on scene and passes duty of continuing line.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Judicial decisions including Privy Council cases

court_reasoning.text: Reviews Privy Council decisions: Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore (1865 10 M.I.A. 279), Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards (1881 L.R. 8 I.A. 229); power incapable when son married/leaves widow as heir.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power ends upon vesting of estate in widow of son.

court_reasoning.text: Affirms Thayammal v. Venkatarama (1887 L.R. 14 I.A. 67), Tarachurn v. Suresh Chunder (1889 L.R. 16 I.A. 166); Full Bench Bombay Ramkrishna v. Shamrao (1902 I.L.R. 26 Bom 526): power extinguished if son leaves son or widow competent to continue line.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle approved in Madana Mohana v. Purushothama (1918 L.R. 45 I.A. 156).

court_reasoning.text: Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan (1933 L.R. 60 I.A. 242): Stress on spiritual duty; interposition of grandson or son's widow ends power; mere birth/attaining competence by son does not; not based on property vesting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty passed to son then to grandson/son's widow ends mother's power; cannot revive.

court_reasoning.text: Rule reaffirmed in Vijaysingji v. Shivsangji (1935 L.R. 62 I.A. 161), Anant Bhikappa v. Shankar (1943 L.R. 70 I.A. 232); part of Hindu Law for three quarters century; consistent with justice, equity, good conscience.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Too late to depart; no substantial grounds to overturn.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects appellant's reliance on Bapuji v. Gangaram and Prem Jagat Kuer: Erroneous, misapprehend Amarendra; power once extinguished cannot revive; duty comes to end.

holdings.text: Widow's power to adopt comes to end by interposition of grandson or son's widow competent to continue line by adoption; once extinguished, cannot revive.

precedents_cited.relevance: Power incapable when son leaves married widow as heir.

precedents_cited.case_name: Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards
precedents_cited.relevance: Power ends on vesting in son's widow; incapable of execution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thayammal and Kuttiswami Aiyan v. Venkatarama Aiyan

precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench: Power extinguished if son leaves son or widow to continue line.
Reoriented to spiritual duty; interposition of grandson/son's widow ends power; no revival.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil

precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous; misapprehends Amarendra; power does not revive on son's widow remarriage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed erroneous Nagpur case; mistaken approval claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shrinivas Krishnarao Kango v. Narayan Devji Kango

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed upholding High Court and trial court; plaintiff's adoption by Gangabai in 1943 invalid as her power ended in 1913 upon son's death leaving widow and grandson competent to continue line.

key_quotes.text: "the power of the former widow is extinguished and can never afterwards be revived."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle from Bombay Full Bench affirmed by Privy Council.

key_quotes.text: "where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father, and was laid by him conditionally upon the mother, has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to a grandson or to the son's widow, the mother's power is gone."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: True basis of rule from Amarendra case.

key_quotes.text: "it is too late in the day to say that there are no limitations of any kind on the widow's power to adopt excepting those that limit the power of her husband to adopt."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court declines to overturn settled rule.
